Posts.Content: Feeling so sorry for you ronstar, life is just not fair! I hope tomorrow is better.  X
Posts.Title: Just some letting off steam after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Dantsa You're not alone, I've been sitting all day today.  I was very active before the FEC-T, to be fair I've been getting out every day to some extent, since the first chemo session  walking a lot with the dogs, and trying to 'be normal' but my second chemo has been  postponed until Tuesday because my white cell count was too low, I wonder if I was over doing it, so today I've been very lazy and I do feel better this evening for it. Don't worry about being a couch potato, its our body telling us something and we need to listen.  Hope things settle down for you soon. Xx
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy side effects

Posts.Content: Hello Loufil22 I was recalled for another a mammogram because of calcifications in my right breast, they showed me the area on the mammogram and said they are quite often begnine, they can be due to an old injury or infection, this proved to be the case with me as they gave me the all clear on the calcifications. While in was there they also biopsied my left breast as I had some cysts, I have had lumpy breasts all my life and have had two begnine cysts removed.  One of the cysts proved to be cancerous a few months later, the calcifications are going to be checked yearly for any changes to be on the safe side. I hope everything turns out good for you, it's a worrying time, I jumped to all sorts of conclusions during the wait for my results and also during my treatment plan, I made myself miserable, I did have cancer but all of the other things I imagined have not materialised, I'm getting through the treatment and things are looking positive. You'll find lots of friendly people here to ask advice and get moral support from if you need it, it has been invaluable for me to be able to come here.  Again, I hope it all turns out good for you on 25th. Xx
Posts.Title: 25 years old and possible breast cancer.

Posts.Content: Hi Jo,  Sorry to hear about your blood  glucose levels. When I was in hospital with the infection just before Christmas I had a blood test when admitted, my levels were high but the nurse doing the test said that it wasn't unusual for people going through chemo and didn't seem worried. Also I'd just taken the steroids and just had the chemo the day before. Ever since then it hasn't been mentioned with all the blood tests so I'm presuming I'm ok now. My Mum was type 1 diabetic and I did have a high reading at the end of my pregnancies. I do hope yours settles down soon. Xx
Posts.Title: Diabetes

Posts.Content: Hello All, I've been a bit busy the last few days with 'work' but I just wanted to share something positive for a change.  I had an appointment with my oncologist today and the ultrasound showed that the two chemo sessions I've had have shrunk the tumour by 50% It's now 2.2 x 1.2cm. I just couldn't believe it. There's still a long way to go, four more sessions but it's certainly a step in the right direction, and to think a few weeks ago when my mastectomy was cancelled and they said it would chemo first I was absolutely devastated. She even said I may have a smaller operation at the end of it now. Also a huge thank you to everyone here for your encouragement. I really do appreciate it. We are all getting there, one day at a time.  Xxx
Posts.Title: The neoadjuvant chemo is working.

Posts.Content: That made me laugh about getting older.  Last year when we landed at the airport after our holiday, as we were leaving the aeroplane the pilot came out of the cockpit, I was so shocked, he looked about twelve years old! I was glad I saw him after we landed. His hat and uniform looked too big for him too.  It did make me feel old.
Posts.Title: The neoadjuvant chemo is working.

Posts.Content: LondonLass Yayyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyy that's fantastic news. So pleased for you Hun! I trust you are having a little celebration tonight!  Any sign of your grandson yet? Xxxx No grandson yet, if he doesn't make an appearance before Tuesday she is  being started off at 2pm.  I'm enjoying tonight, last night I was in a bit of a state worrying about today. I think I will sleep well tonight!  Hope your job is going well LondonLass.
Posts.Title: The neoadjuvant chemo is working.

Posts.Content: Scotty66 Fantastic news. I had my first FEC-T yesterday and that is exactly the sort of post I wanted to hear. By the way I hope your grandchild is born today .It's my sons 18th today and he's an absolute cracker! x Hi Scotty66 I hope you find the chemo manageable, I have so far, I think I've been lucky there. One more FEC on Tuesday then another check up on 13th Feb to see whats going on... then the T bit starts, I'm a bit worried about the T sessions but at least thats the half way mark. No grandson today by the looks of it, so he won't share your sons birthday, he's taking after his mum, she was two weeks late, in fact both of my daughters were. I am so, so excited to go and see them next week.   All the best to you Scotty. Xxx
Posts.Title: The neoadjuvant chemo is working.

Posts.Content: So pleased to hear you are back at home Jo and it's all done. It's a great feeling isn't it?  Definitely do the exercises,  I found them a bit painful to start with, but after about 3-4 days they were fine and I have no pain at all now. My BC nurse said take paracetamol 20 mins before you do them for the first couple of days. My scars are healing really well now all the glue has come away, I'm amazed at how good it all looks so soon after the op. I think I'll have a blue boob for a while though.  All the best Jo and enjoy that feeling of having the operation out of the way and have a good rest.  Xx
Posts.Title: Surgery yesterday

Posts.Content: LondonLass I am so pleased you are home, I've been checking to see if you're ok every time I've sat down, which is quite a lot! Such a relief you are on the mend. You're such an inspiration to everyone, it's time to spoil yourself now and take it easy.  You've put a smile on my face knowing you are at home. Hugs to you. Xxx
Posts.Title: THANKYOU SO MUCH

Posts.Content: I live in Wales, but I've signed it, Xx
Posts.Title: petition the government to continue Kadcyla for breast cancer patients...

Posts.Content: LondonLass Thanks for all the lovely messages of support. Biopsy done. Results possibly by next week, but could take up to 3 weeks.  Feeling extremely sorry for myself, hoping the pain will settle and tomorrow will be a better day........it definitly can't be any worse xxx LondonLass, I truly hope and pray that tomorrow is a better day for you, I've been thinking about you all day. We are all here for you, as you are always for us.  Sending love and a hug to you, lovely lady. Xx
Posts.Title: Have to be honest.....

Posts.Content: Hello LondonLass, I'm so sorry you're going through this. You've been a tremendous help to me, I just wish I could say something to help you feel better. But I am thinking of you now as I often do and I'm so hoping things pick up for you very soon.  Sending a big hug to you. Xxx
Posts.Title: Have to be honest.....

Posts.Content: LondonLass Thanks for all the lovely messages of support. Biopsy done. Results possibly by next week, but could take up to 3 weeks.  Feeling extremely sorry for myself, hoping the pain will settle and tomorrow will be a better day........it definitly can't be any worse xxx LondonLass, I truly hope and pray that tomorrow is a better day for you, I've been thinking about you all day. We are all here for you, as you are always for us.  Sending love and a hug to you, lovely lady. Xx
Posts.Title: Have to be honest.....

Posts.Content: Hello Asm5711, I hope today goes well for you, I really do. You are not alone,  I am in the same situation, I start chemo today as well, 1.30pm, then eventually surgery after the chemo, thats the plan, hopefully this will have shrunk  this cancer down and the mastectomy will give better results.  I was counting down the hours until the start of treatment, so that then I could feel that at least my body is fighting back. I'm looking at it like this, When I feel crappy over the next few days, weeks, months, then the cancer cells will be feeling even crappier and thats a good  thing! And when I don't feel crappy, I'll make the most of it. My husband just walked by and  said, big day today...hooter starts the fight back! Made me smile. He's a gem.  Its nearly 8.30am so I'm sending you a virtual hug and hoping all will be well today.
Posts.Title: Here goes...first day of chemo

Posts.Content: Thanks cyrstaljuju, I do have thick hair but it's gone very dry in the last two weeks, yesterday my scalp felt a bit itchy. Maybe I will leave it for a bit longer to see what happens. I banged my head today and have a lump on it, so if it all falls out tonight I'll look even worse, just my luck. Thanks Julia.  Xx
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: Hello elaineo2 I'm wondering what it will feel like to actually go out wearing my wig, I think tomorrow I will wear it during the day to get used to it. It does look lovely and shiny, my hair was thick and shiny but it's gone all dull lately, plus I missed the last hair cut, and my roots are showing through so maybe i will look better with the wig. When it starts to grow long enough to cut I'm going to take the wig to my hairdresser and ask for the same cut and colour as I can never explain what I want properly.  The wig lady got it spot on though.  Janette xx
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: Hi toxophilite,  I thought mine might last a little longer, maybe it'll just keep thinning, I do have a lot of hair. I never thought about nose hair, I bet it itches when it grows back.   I bought a hat off the internet, I thought it looked lovely, supposed to make it look like you have hair underneath, when it came it was quite thin and just had a band like an infinity scarf you wrap around the hat.  It does look good when I play around with it, but it was a lot of money for what it was. My husband said ' stick a pair of pants or socks under a normal hat, that'll fill it out!' I think I'll just wear hats or scarves most of the time indoors.  Hope your arm is better now.  Xxx
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: Hi jowoomot, You're probably right and no one was looking at you today, but I bet we all feel like that to start with. I know I will. I was so shocked at how real the wigs looked when I went to the wig lady, I'm sure I wouldn't be able to tell if someone was wearing one.  I'll probably put mine on wrong though, my husband put a mark on my cycle helmet because I kept putting it on backwards,  I had long hair until about two years ago,then had it cut into a graduated bob, my hair is thick and curly so I was straightening it a lot, so it went to a longish pixie, I'd just got it about right a couple of months ago...oh well never mind.  I am curious to see what will grow back though, my neighbour said you will get chemo curl, and that's all I need on top of curly hair. It'll probably be quite grey too. I don't mind losing it from my private parts, I'd trade that for eyelashes and brows any day. I've been looking on YouTube, there's a lady on there who does amazing eyebrows, I just need to get the pencil and bits, she uses stick on lashes too but I don't think I could use them, but you never know. Maybe for a special occasion.  I hope your treatment goes well  for you Jo. Xxx
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: Hi jojo, I really feel for you, I know how you're feeling, but you are in the right place here to find comfort and support.  It's the waiting and feeling that you're not in control that's the terrifying bit, but it does get better. I have been writing a blog for the first time ever so that I can look back one day and remind myself that things do indeed get better. They are already  I won't go into huge detail because it's all on there, but I hope I can make you feel a little better by saying that,yesterday I went for my pre chemo meeting with my oncologist. She went into great detail, as I am now having chemotherapy first to try to shrink the tumour before mastectomy, plus it'll treat the whole body at the same time, my tumour is large, 42mm, its grade 3 invasive. But they are very positive of a good outcome.  The scans were a stressful time, they each took longer than they estimated and a couple were done twice. Then on top of that I had to have an MRI on my liver as there was a question mark over it. My mind was in overdrive!   I scared myself silly,  I'd convinced myself that it'd spread, because they put me back in on the bone scan, plus I got a phone call at 5.45pm last Thursday to say my results were in and they needed to see me first thing in the morning for a discussion about the findings. I convinced my self it was the worst case scenario. What a horrendous night! But it was to say that they were changing my treatment plan to chemo first as the tumour was large, but my scans were clear! The tumour is large but has stayed put so far with no evidence yet of lymph node involvement. So I just wanted to say that the time between diagnosis and getting a treatment is the worst, and your imagination will go wild...but take comfort in knowing that they are the experts and are busy getting all the information together during that time so they can treat you in the best way that suits your individual situation. Also if like me, the scans take longer, or they pop you back in again at the end, please don't panic, they are just being thorough.  I hope that helps a little. X
Posts.Title: 2nd night of waiting: even more terrified

Posts.Content: Hello All, Silly question but I never thought to ask the wig lady or chemotherapy nurse how it would actually happen when it does.  I'm only 12 days into my first chemo and my hair is starting to come out. I know it's inevitable and I'm ready for it, but does any one know if it will carry on coming out slowly or if it will come out in big clumps, or is it that everyone is different. I have the hubbys clippers ready. In a way I just want it over with. Xx
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: Hi jojo,  I do have a wig thanks jo, the hospital gave me a voucher, I couldn't believe my luck because I live in the middle of nowhere, but there's a fantastic wig lady just ten minutes away.  I bought some sleep hats and a couple for under head scarves off the internet, and also some pretty scarves. Then I went on YouTube, I can do a mean head wrap now, but I think it will be easier when my hair has gone in a way. I'm coping well I think now, suddenly I feel more positive about things, I still have moments of sadness and fear, but they are getting less now, and I am sleeping a bit better. How are you getting on jo? Do you have a date for your chemotherapy to start yet?  Xxx
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: Oh my goodness, worried2016, You have had such a lot to put up with already this year, just think how strong you're going to be after all of this!  I don't know what to say except that joining Macmillan was the best thing that I ever did, I honestly don't know where I'd be now without the advice and support I've had from here. 24/7 I know what you mean about not having cancer conversations every day, my dad has Alzheimer's, he forgets everything, but not this! It's on repeat every day, over and over!  I had the same thing, feeling like it was growing, I think it's quite common. I won't bore you with my 'story' but I just wanted to say hello, you're not alone in this, I had times where I wanted to give up, thought it was all pointless, too exhausted to think straight, but it's getting better now, little by little, bit by bit, just think that each scan and every appointment gets you nearer to your treatment plan, and further away from the 'not knowing' stage. Better go, the dogs are awake and begging for a wee and breakfast! Xx
Posts.Title: 2nd night of waiting: even more terrified

Posts.Content: Hi Tray41 Thanks for the info, I am just on day 12 of FEC-T and that's when it's started shedding also, it's been interesting hearing different peoples experiences, I have a feeling that I'll probably brave the shave in a few days, if not before, my hair is looking so awful anyway now. I might just wrap my head up in a scarf tomorrow and collect all the fall out at the end of the day.  I don't care what people think of me either, my husband is the important one, he has to look at me all day, I only see me in the mirror, and I can avoid that to a certain extent. He's not in the least bit bothered either way, but thinks I'd be happier getting the job done if it starts looking more of a mess, he knows me well. Thanks again Tracey, so glad your chemotherapy is over, and in time for Christmas.  Wishing you all the very best for the future. Janette xx
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: Hi kacang, It's two week tomorrow when I had my first session of FEC-T. This morning it's really noticeable. I went to the shops with my hat on but now I'm back home I've just put a scarf on to catch the loose hair.  I said to my husband , I think I'm going to brave the shave pretty soon,  he said maybe that means I will shave the brave!  It is a strange feeling like you said, I might give it a good brush later and see what's left.  Someone just came to the door and I whipped my scarf off, that's not good, I should've left it on really. Plus my own hair looks such a mess now?  Anyway thanks kacang, it's been interesting hearing how other people found the hair loss experience. I'd better get some jobs done.  Xx
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: Thanks for the info Bedford69, It's two weeks for me tomorrow, it sounds fairly normal. I'm going to get the clippers out tomorrow because it looks awful and the weird feeling is irritating me, it's like when you part your hair the other side, that's the only way I can describe it. Your hair sounds like it grows fast!  Thanks for the information  Bedford 69 and I hope all is going well for you now. Xxx
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: Update,  The hair has been clippered off, well nearly, it was dropping out and looking Awful, so I got the scissors out, why I don't know, I just wanted to play with it, like when I was a child with my Barbie doll. Anyway I soon got bored with that so took the clippers to it.  I said to my husband that it wouldn't as short go to 1.5 m, it's slightly longer... he looked a bit sheepish and said it was  set on his beard stubbly length, so now I have a beard head.  The last bits will flick off easily now I hope and not annoy me so much.
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: toxophilite that made me smile, Glad your arm is on the mend. Can you imagine if you were wearing the head eating shark hat at the same time as blood running down your arm and dripping off your fingers, I bet there wouldn't be a queue for the parking meter!  I'm sitting here blowing hairs off my iPad screen! It's slowly going. I'm going to watch some tv now and stop fiddling with my hair. Xx
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: Wine belly, you must have super strength hair! I've decided tomorrow is the day, I just can't stand the hair dropping everywhere. Plus it's starting to look really bad now anyway. I hope we don't get anybody knock on the door tonight, I'll have to keep a hat handy. All the best to you. X
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: Me to jojo, I never thought about it either, my eyebrows are still there, and eyelashes but I'm not getting my hopes up that they'll stay ...everything else hairy can go though. Maybe we will feel the cold more though!  How are you doing jo? Xx
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: Hi jojo, It's good that you're feeling better, even though it sounds like a stressful journey home, I'm glad you didn't find the marker clip too bad, I've got a matching pair now. I was watching when she put it in, it just floated into the tumour, it was really strange to be looking at the damn thing. So far the chemo has been kind to me I think. All I've had really is a slight headache for a day or so, a thick nose feeling. Oh and 'fluffy' gums for a few days. No sickness at all. I told my daughter that my hair was coming out today, she said "Well at least you know it's doing something Mum." It's hard for the husbands isn't it? Mine has been so supportive, he's even been doing some cooking, I could cook, but he seems to be enjoying doing it, he's also been working hard outside, I think to try to keep busy in an attempt  to take his mind of things, I've noticed that he is napping a lot, every time he sits down nearly, I'm sure it's stress, it's a it better the last couple of days though.  I'm hoping tomorrow is a positive day for you jo, do let me know how you get on. Xxxx
Posts.Title: Curious about when my hair will fall out.

Posts.Content: It's crazy, what's going on?  I didn't sleep a wink last night..not even a minute, hoping for some zzzz's tonight, if nothing happens by 11pm I'm going to take a sleeping tablet. I've had 7 hrs sleep in 3 nights. I'm really fed up with it now.
Posts.Title: 2hrs Sleep....

Posts.Content: Hi jo, My pre chemo appointment was similar to what all the others are saying, drinking plenty of water the day before is great advice, my chemo nurse also advised that. I did and it made a difference to my veins, I could actually see the veins had 'popped up' she was very pleased when I turned up all 'veiny' the next day. I've been drinking loads of water ever since, and will definitely  keep it up, it does help with flushing through after chemo. Again it was blood pressure, bloods, and signing the form at the pre chemo appointment.  I'm thinking of you jo, my next dose is on Friday.  Xxx
Posts.Title: Appointment cancelled

Posts.Content: Hello Sussaneg, This sounds much better than I was imagining, I know everyone is different, but I am more hopeful about being able to do the Christmas visit now. I'm so so sorry if I've butted in on somebody else's info request, I'm not too familiar with computers and could be putting these replies in the wrong place.Im not worried about the actual op, But I am absolutely terrified of the scans next week, the ct and bone scan. Nobody would guess by looking at me but I am...I wish I could fast forward a week.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - any advice please?

Posts.Content: Hello Katie, I was just about to go to sleep, sorry, try to go to sleep, when I saw your reply. I will be thinking of you on Monday, I get admitted on the same Monday, as I live a fair distance from the hospital, Ive been told to turn up early Monday then you go by taxi to another hospital and get an injection and come back to the hospital followed by the Op on Tuesday. If you are planning the nativity then thats great, I'm so hoping to make the Christmas gathering. Its just a long way from the hospital for me, so Im hoping everything has finished draining by then. I'm with you on the chemo thoughts. I suppose they have to let you settle down a bit after the operation before starting it. I wonder where you take the wig voucher? This is all so new and strange, like another world, but a world full of lovely people willing to help and give advice.  Xxx
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - any advice please?

Posts.Content: Hello KatieF We are in a similar position, I was diagnosed with a grade 3 breast tumour just over a week ago, a bolt out of the blue after having the all clear recently, my surgery for a mastectomy is on 22 Nov, with radiotherapy and chemo to follow, maybe other treatments, its still sinking in. I asked the breast care nurse if it would be ok to go to my daughters in London over Christmas (I live in W. Wales) as she is due to have her first baby on 29th Dec, she said most likely it would be fine, I was so relieved, but I had no idea about the drains they leave in, then take out, she said you can get fluid build up after they take out the drains, and have to have it drained out.  I hope I can go. She didn't mention to me about any further treatment before Christmas so I'm guessing that will kick off in the new year. I've been told I will get a wig. I wasn't really expecting to be given a wig, it's very kind to be given one. I hope your meeting with the consultant and your surgery goes well.  Xx
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - any advice please?

Posts.Content: Thank you IslandGirl, I'm so pleased to read these comments on the drains,  any little positive I can get is helping. I know everyone is different, my husband did say maybe the breast care nurse was giving me worst case scenario, she said I'd be in for seven days, but I'm hoping it won't be that long. Thanks again.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - any advice please?

Posts.Content: Hello 4paws. I joined Macmillan last week after my diagnosis, long story, but a hell of a shock as it is for everyone. It was the best thing I did to join I got a lovely welcome straight away, that was such a boost to me when I really really needed it, as I was in a dark place. Since then I have been on here a lot, it makes me feel much better, people willingly give such good advice.   I hope you find your way around the site. I'm slowly getting the hang of it.  My mastectomy is a week tomorrow so I cant help you with your question as its all new to me too, but I just wanted to say hello. Xx
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - any advice please?

Posts.Content: Thanks ronstar,  That sounds encouraging, It so nice to get some feedback from people who have been there. Nice to hear things are setting down for you now. I only know one person who has had breast cancer and she is amazing, but away for the next two weeks.  I was so concerned that the drains might stop me going to my daughters at Christmas as my other daughter will be there too. i didn't want to spoil  Christmas for everyone. Thanks once more.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed - any advice please?

Posts.Content: Hi jo, My pre chemo appointment was similar to what all the others are saying, drinking plenty of water the day before is great advice, my chemo nurse also advised that. I did and it made a difference to my veins, I could actually see the veins had 'popped up' she was very pleased when I turned up all 'veiny' the next day. I've been drinking loads of water ever since, and will definitely  keep it up, it does help with flushing through after chemo. Again it was blood pressure, bloods, and signing the form at the pre chemo appointment.  I'm thinking of you jo, my next dose is on Friday.  Xxx
Posts.Title: Appointment cancelled

Posts.Content: Hello everyone. I haven't had time to post on here with everything going on but I have  been thinking of you all and hoping all is good with you all, I also wanted to say a huge thank you for all the  friendly words of encouragement you've given me lately. Time to head home later for me and I'm not looking forward to that, but I got to visit my daughters for Christmas, that was the best Christmas present for me and my husband and a blessing.  Xx
Posts.Title: Hoping everyone is enjoying the holiday.

Posts.Content: Hello. I just wanted to say that I can have the second FEC-T tomorrow, the chemotherapy nurse just phoned to say my bloods were fine, I'm so relieved. I may get a better nights sleep tonight.  Thank you to every who reassured me when it was postponed on Friday. I still had a worrisome weekend but it would've been worse without the kind words.  Xx
Posts.Title: All clear for the second FEC-T tomorrow.

Posts.Content: Thank you for the kind words, it means a lot. I will wait until I've met the breast care nurse tomorrow before I decide wether to tell my daughters, the older one is due to have her first baby and is moving into her new house tomorrow. I can't spoil that for her. My husband is here with me, so we will comfort each other tonight. Again, Thank you so much, it's so nice when someone listens. Xx
Posts.Title: I need help please.

Posts.Content: Hello G n J Thanks for the hope that it's something minor, wouldn't that be lovely, but I don't think that's the case. I'm preparing myself for the worst now. I can't stop thinking about my daughters though, this is a nightmare. I did phone the Macmillan helpline straight after the nurse phoned. They were lovely, don't they do a marvellous job. She didn't give me a time, just said come to see to discuss the scan results me at your convenience between 10-12 o'clock. She had her sad voice on, and wouldn't give anything away. Thank you all for your good wishes though, I'm sure I'll let you know the outcome. Xx
Posts.Title: I need help please.

Posts.Content: Hello grog  Thanks for the hope of better news, but it's a huge lump now, has grown since diagnosis two week ago. I felt a lump under my armpit last  night too, that wasn't there yesterday. I felt powerless during this two weeks, I could see it getting bigger, I phoned twice to say this, but it seems that they won't do anything during that time between diagnosis and operating. I suppose they need the scan results first, but it seems so cruel.  The scans were the ct scan and bone scan (with the radioactive fluid) she did a second one on the bones, a 360 degree one. I have grade 3 invasive cancer.  I've had many needle biopsies and VAB's over the last few months, I was told the left breast wasn't a concern, given the all clear at the end of August but told that the right breast needed to be monitored as I have calcium deposits. It's complicated.   Thanks for the reply though, at least I don't have too long to wait now.  Xx
Posts.Title: I need help please.

Posts.Content: Hello All,  I am desperate, really desperate, my mastectomy is booked for Tuesday, with admission on Monday, I just got a phone call from the breast care nurse saying to go to the clinic tomorrow to discuss my scan results. I am sitting here shaking feeling sick, does anyone have any words to help me right now?
Posts.Title: I need help please.

Posts.Content: Hello lacomtkp, It's complicated 'story' I have lots of cysts in my left breast, these were needle biopsied in July, the right breast too. Left breast given the all clear, and right breast had VAB the next month for the calcifications. I was given the all clear in Aughust and told to go back to 3 yearly mammograms, a week later I had a phone call to say that actually they would see me in a year.  I noticed a lump on my left side in September, it felt like fluid, l left it a little while thinking that I'd had the all clear and that it was another  cyst, it got bigger so I went to my gp in October he also thought it was a cyst, but referred me back to the hospital. It was drained and that's when she found a lump underneath. She took 2 needle biopsies and the results came back as grade 3 cancer. The cyst had returned two days after being drained. I was booked in for a mastectomy on 22 Nov. During the next two weeks the 'cyst' got bigger so I phoned the breast care nurse to ask if something needed doing, she said I was probably imagining it and that I was on a treatment plan now and nothing would be done until the operation.  I called again a week later, I was very worried by now, to say it was now painful and uncomfortable it was but perhaps that was the cyst growing, not the cancer, she then dropped the bombshell that I don't have a cyst, it's the cancer. I was devastated. It was still a week to go for the operation at this point. I think I knew then that this wasn't going to be a good outcome. Sorry for the long reply, I got carried away!  Thanks for the cyber hug, and I'll keep you updated. xx
Posts.Title: I need help please.

Posts.Content: Thank you Julia,  I'm about to leave, it's a long drive.  Xx
Posts.Title: I need help please.

Posts.Content: Hello All, Just wondering about nails, mine have been great up until a couple of days ago, now they look a bit bruised under the nail. They feel bruised too, no tingling though. Has anyone else had this and is this the start of losing my nails? I thought they were doing so well until this.  On the plus side, I'm pretty sure my hair is growing again. I got the magnifying light up mirror out!
Posts.Title: Nails on 'T'

Posts.Content: Hello everyone. I hope you are all as good as you can be on the chemotherapy. I had my ultrasound today and was relieved to find the lump had shrunk again, I am so silly, I had convinced myself that it had stopped shrinking and even got bigger during the last few days, I have a good imagination and always seem to do this to myself before appointments.  Anyway from 4.2cm originally,  to 2.2cm X 1.1 cm after 2x FEC cycles. Jump forward to today and the  measurements after 3FEC and 1x T cycles were 0.9cm x 0.6cm with two T cycles still to go. To say I was  relieved and absolutely over the moon is an understatement.   She was very pleased and said it's looking like a lumpectomy instead of a mastectomy now, also she arranged the surgery for 4th April... it's my birthday. I've got to go back on 20th March for one more check and to discuss in detail with her what will happen with surgery.  The end of the chemo really does seem in sight now I have the surgery date.  Xx
Posts.Title: More shrinkage on 'T' chemo.

Posts.Content: Hi Kacang, Thank you I do hope that happens , she did seem very pleased and said that by the end of the next two sessions she's hoping to see just the marker clip on the scan, she said the clip seems to be just sitting in some residue material now. I'm not getting my hopes up too much though, after getting the all clear last year I know what it feels like to have good news backfire. (But I can't help feeling optimistic, ssshhhh, who said that?)  Xx
Posts.Title: More shrinkage on 'T' chemo.

Posts.Content: That's great news, worried 2016, absolutely fantastic. So so pleased for you. Xx
Posts.Title: I have my results

Posts.Content: Good morning all, I posted this on breast cancer, but wanted put it here too. I know this isn't chemo related but I wanted you all to know my daughter had her baby boy at 6.31am all is good, I am absolutely ecstatic! Both are well, and  he has so much hair!  Thank you to everyone who is helping me through this treatment, I know things are a long way from perfect and I can't get to them until Tuesday after my chemo, but I am going then and I just can't wait.  This is it now...things are looking up. I didn't think I could feel this happy. I am crying with happiness today, that makes a change!
Posts.Title: Good morning all it happend, I'm a grandma.

Posts.Content: Thanks puzzler. I am a fit healthy person ( how ironic) but this last week has knocked me for six, I can go for a year or more without getting a cold, but when I do its usually bad and ends up with sinusitis and it drags on. We live in the countryside in Wales, our business is closed at the moment as its our quiet time anyway, so I won't  be coming in contact with many people next week. I went out yesterday as I am visiting my younger daughter this weekend. I wrapped up, Im taking high dose vit c. and I'm washing my hands all the time. Its one thing trying to prevent catching a cold, but my husband has now said I would be silly to walk into that environment. He doesn't want me to go, but he has to go as he's helping them to move house. I'm not looking forward to being on my own before the op, but its not for long really. We go back to Wales tomorrow. My daughter works in operating theatres so she will probably tell me not to go anyway, she is desperate for me to have the operation done then. Thanks again for the reply. I appreciate  your take on things. Xx
Posts.Title: Colds and visitors.

Posts.Content: Good morning zappaman,  I am sitting with a cup of tea all cozy and warm with my younger daughter, her fiancé and my husband, decision made...I'm not going to go. None of them want me to go, I will stay behind  and have lots of walks and cuddles mith my doggies. I will be visiting her in her new place for Christmas (God willing) and hopefully staying until she has the baby. Thanks again for your advice.  Better go the magic porridge pan is out! Sending a lovely hug to you all.
Posts.Title: Colds and visitors.

Posts.Content: Hello Wendy woo, How lovely that your sister has you looking out for her. I had trouble sleeping before my chemotherapy, my breast care nurse suggested I got some sleeping tablets from my GP. I didn't follow her advice then but when I went to see my oncologist just before chemotherapy she arranged for me to get a weeks supply there and then at the hospital. I had tried all the sleep apps on my phone, lavender smelling pillows, relaxation techniques etc etc, but nothing worked for me. The sleeping tablets are just mild ones but they just send me off to sleep, I still only manage 5 ish hours sleep but it's a lot better than before and it's getting better. I don't intend to use them for long and will try without tonight and see what happens.  I did get some more from my GP when the weeks supply ran out. It is such a welcome relief to have some rest. I would normally not touch sleeping tablets and just battle through, but these are not normal times.  Maybe someone else  here will have another solution that might help your sister. Wendy woo, I wish you and your sister all the very best, I'm sure you are a great comfort to her.  Xx
Posts.Title: Unable to sleep post chemo.

Posts.Content: Thanks Baki, I took a couple of mild sleeping tablets in the end last night and got a little sleep so I am thinking a little clearer this morning.  I am pretty sure I will stay behind, we always go to see her in November when our business shuts down for a bit, and when I think about it, without doubt every year we've come back with a cold. Can't cope with the London germs! I think my mind is made up, it's getting quite achy around where the lump is, probably just because there's a large cyst on top Of it, but this is worrying me such a lot, so to delay the op would be the devastating for me mentally too.  Thanks for your thoughts on the matter and the reply. X
Posts.Title: Colds and visitors.

Posts.Content: Hello all, Another sleepless night.... I am due to have a mastectomy on Tues 22 Nov. I am being admitted on Monday 21st. I'm supposed to be going to visit my daughter on Friday and coming back Saturday 19th. Today she told me that she is full of cold and so is her partner, I so want to visit as it is going to be some time before I can see her, she lives quite a distance away.I don't think I could take it if the operation was cancelled, Im thinking thats what they would do if I had a cold. I think she will probably tell me not to go anyway. It seems to be one thing after another lately. Does anyone know when you are contagious with a cold?
Posts.Title: Colds and visitors.

Posts.Content: Hello Wendy woo, How lovely that your sister has you looking out for her. I had trouble sleeping before my chemotherapy, my breast care nurse suggested I got some sleeping tablets from my GP. I didn't follow her advice then but when I went to see my oncologist just before chemotherapy she arranged for me to get a weeks supply there and then at the hospital. I had tried all the sleep apps on my phone, lavender smelling pillows, relaxation techniques etc etc, but nothing worked for me. The sleeping tablets are just mild ones but they just send me off to sleep, I still only manage 5 ish hours sleep but it's a lot better than before and it's getting better. I don't intend to use them for long and will try without tonight and see what happens.  I did get some more from my GP when the weeks supply ran out. It is such a welcome relief to have some rest. I would normally not touch sleeping tablets and just battle through, but these are not normal times.  Maybe someone else  here will have another solution that might help your sister. Wendy woo, I wish you and your sister all the very best, I'm sure you are a great comfort to her.  Xx
Posts.Title: Unable to sleep post chemo.

Posts.Content: Hi jo,  You're doing well, I bet a couple of weeks ago you couldn't imagine even having a couple of good days. Hope you've finished with your 30 minutes now and are feeling a bit happier now.  Xx
Posts.Title: Recipe for mouthwask

Posts.Content: Hello silkpainter,  I feel for you, this is the place to rant though, we all understand. It's quite normal to feel angry when you've had your life turned upsidedown in just a second, it  takes a hell of a lot of dealing with, I still can't believe its happening to me sometimes. We know that logically your husband is right, but it doesn't make it any easier to deal with does it. Especially at this time of year, absolutely everything seems harder to deal with.  I can't say anything to help with the anxiety of waiting, but you will find lots of people to talk to here, it does help enormously.  Hopefully your scan will come back clear, but in the meantime we are all here for you. Xxx
Posts.Title: Ever so slightly stunned ! Please not again.

Posts.Content: Hello Nanny Jan. Sorry to hear about your daughter, when I was in hospital just before Christmas I was surrounded by ladies who had this awful cough, I had a bit of a chest infection and was on iv antibiotics, luckily I didn't catch the cough, but they'd had it for a while.  I was given antibiotics to take home after a couple of days and am about to have my next chemo session today, it hasn't stopped me having treatment. From what I've read in the newspapers it sounds like there are so many people with this cough.  I do hope your daughter gets home soon. Xxx
Posts.Title: Currently in hospital

Posts.Content: Hello everyone.  I was diagnosed with a grade 3 invasive breast cancer on Friday 4th Nov. I am waiting for my mastectomy surgery which will be two weeks today. I was shocked at the news as over the last six months I've been having quite a few investigations with biopsies and they've all come back clear, this lump came up on my left breast, I was told that breast wasn't an issue, it was a cyst again, but large, so they drained it, but then found this lump underneath. Turned out to be cancer. We had our daughter and partner visiting for the weekend so I was kept busy, but since she's gone home the reality is sinking in, waking up at 3am worrying that it has spread as I get pains around the cyst, infact every little twinge is worrying me.  I'm usually the person who is positive, glass is always half full sort, but this has knocked me sideways. But I have become a good actor since Friday, no one would know what's going on inside my head by looking at me. Anyway it's Pre op tomorrow, bone scan, CT scan...oh how life can change in a heartbeat. We were due to start a two week holiday tomorrow. Anyway I decided to join Macmillan, most unlike me as I'm quite a private person, plus rubbish at technology, but I thought everyone on here sounded so lovely and honest so it wouldn't harm. I don't want to take up my lovely husbands offer to wake him up if I can't sleep, no point us both being tired. I hope I've done this right. Apologies for rambling on. JMC04
Posts.Title: The long wait.

Posts.Content: Hello Kacang Thanks for the message and good wishes. I like the sound of your onco. I was just about to go out to the pre op but just wanted to say thank you. I have found it a huge comfort seeing these messages, and I've only been here for a day, I will probably have questions later when I get back, unless my breast care nurse is able to answer them, problem is I don't really know what to ask! My main one is if I will be able to visit my daughter for Christmas, she's expecting her first baby and our first grandchild on 29th Dec and wants us there. Obviously she will understand if I can't, but that would be awful. I will ask her if everything goes to plan, what the chances are.  Many thanks again.xx
Posts.Title: The long wait.

Posts.Content: Thank you Millie99 Any encouraging news is great to hear, so pleased you got a clear result, hope it's the start of many more. I think my husband has just about filled every day until the op with something now, so the 'long wait' won't seem so long hopefully. Oh how life can totally change though,in such a short time, and how you realise that you can cope with more than you ever thought possible. My husband and I saw the breast care nurse today, before the pre op,  she was great and made us both feel much better. I'd had a mini melt down in the TK max car park, only lasted two minutes, my first tears since being diagnosed, what a place to have them! I think it was me buying my nice new pyjamas and bits, for the hospital  and everyone else being so jolly doing Christmas Shopping. Anyway I'm going to try to sleep as I've got a busy day tomorrow. Many thanks again for the hope and the virtual hug. Xx
Posts.Title: The long wait.

Posts.Content: Hello,  Oh my goodness, poor you, what awfully bad luck, both of you getting this terrible disease! I hope those side effects wear off soon. I'm not sure what to do when and if the time comes about a breast reconstruction, the consultant said she'd discuss it at a later date. Problem being that my other breast, the right breast has calcification in it. They say that's not a concern at the moment, just needs watching for changes. My daughter is in the medical profession and works in the operating theatres has asked me to consider having the other side taken away later as she doesn't want me worrying about that side too, I think she is desperate for anything dodgy to go. I can't pull the wool over her eyes or make it sound better than it is for her sake. (She's expecting her first baby in December and I didn't want her worrying) she knows the procedure with bone scan ct scan etc.  I guess I will wait and see how well this turns out first and how I feel and if its spread or not. Stage 3 sounds scary to me right now! What is FEC-D? Sorry but I don't know much about the after treatment, seems so many different types. The consultant mentioned chemo and radiation I think, I wasn't really taking it all in.  Think I'll find out more at the pre op tomorrow. If you want to chat in the early hours and I'm on here feel free to say hello, I think my nights are going to be very different for a while.  I have no friends on here yet and am trying to get the hang of how it all works. Bye for now, and bless you for replying.
Posts.Title: The long wait.

Posts.Content: Hello Carolyn, Well, you asked what inspired all the biopsies, are you ready, here we go. Similar to you really, I've had Breast cysts for many years, with two begin lumps operated on and removed, had a call up for my 50th year mammograms in June. I told my hubby that I didn't want to go, that it would be 'opening up a can of worms'...boy was I right!  I got a recall letter 10 days later, appointment at breast care on July 6th. This resulted in I think (I lost count) about 12 needle biopsies, both sides. The results came in on 8 July as left breast OK but inconclusive on breast calcification on the right side, so back to have VAB on 2nd August quite a few, I was told this VAB would only be one needle and would be easier than the last lot, but it wasn't, it was very painful and they did loads. It took until 26 August to get the results and many phone calls, I got the all clear that day and was told 3 yearly checks would be fine. I would get a letter stating this, I never got the letter so started phoning to see why I hadn't got it, but then I had a lump come up on the left breast, which was the one they weren't concerned with, I left it for a month before seeing the GP (Oct 13)as they hadn't been concerned about the lumps in the left side I thought it'd just be another begnine cyst, when it started to get big I thought I'd better go. So it was a referral back to the hospital last Monday and the cyst was drained with loads of clear fluid removed, she seemed pleased and I was so relieved ...but then she ultrasounded the area again and that was when the lump underneath the cyst showed up, she looked back at the mammograms from June/July and she thought it wasn't present then, two more needle biopsies into the lump and then on Friday when getting the results the awful news came that it was indeed cancer, grade3 an invasive type. That's how I got here. Long story, sorry. On the sleep side of things, I have some very mild sleeping tablets from a while ago, I only took a few then and have some left, but I don't want to go down that route yet if I can help it, but sleep makes things so much easier to cope with so I might give in. Oh you did make me smile when you said your husband woke you up to make sure you were ok.  Blimey though it sounds like you've been through it all. If only we could go back do things differently hey? I wouldn't have waited so long to go back with this last lump. Hindsight is a wonderful thing.  Janette, xx
Posts.Title: The long wait.

Posts.Content: Hello again Carolyn, I've been thinking a lot about reasons for cancer at this time of life. I've always been prone to breast changes around my period, I had a break of 3 months this year May, June, July with no periods, I thought oh well, here we go, it's the start of the menopause, actually wanted to get it over with, no more lumpy painful boobs every month, during that 3 months they were much better, I slept better, then in August I had a period, very heavy, then two weeks later another one, then in September a period, my last period was October 5th, so they may be stopping again as I'm a week late now, with no sign of anything. Is it hormones with me, that's what I'm asking myself. About the reconstruction I think she did mention radiotherapy, but it was all a bit of a blur but  she said we could discuss reconstruction at a later date. She did also say she could just remove the lump and surrounding tissue if I really wanted, but wouldn't be really happy with that because of my lumpy history. I think she's a 'belt and braces' approach type of person.  I will ask  tomorrow what sort of cancer it is.  I took your advice and have ignored the housework.  Janette xx
Posts.Title: The long wait.

Posts.Content: Hello Loulou 1007, Thanks for the encouraging words, so nice to see that you are coming out the other side now, I'm going for my pre op soon, I'm not too bothered about it as it sounds like it's a check to see if you are fit enough for the op. I've always kept fit, ran a 5k park run with my daughter a month ago and wasn't far behind her. Isn't that ironic? I've always been careful with my diet and weight, now I feel like it's been all for nothing. It's the scans next week I'm dreading.   Today I'm feeling a little tearful, and weary, I don't know why because I haven't even cried yet, plus we are taking a last chance before the op to visit family in Devon over the weekend, leaving tomorrow, I should be happy. I need to find my 'actors hat' and put it on I think. This is exactly how I felt ten years ago after my mum died. Anyway thanks for the positivity, very much appreciated right now. Xx
Posts.Title: The long wait.

Posts.Content: Oh my goodness Chick.36, I feel for you, i don't know what to say because I haven't had my op yet, but from what others say, you'll get there, as you said you've three little boys to get better for. My daughters have left home, so I don't have that worry.  I hope you've plenty of help with the little ones. I've got the hubby in the spare room so he doesn't wake me up with his snoring, I've swapped him for my little dog, its naughty but he's sneaked onto the bed from his dog bed for a cuddle, I think he knows I need a hug. I think I'll leave him there. I'm keeping my fingers crossed that you feel better asap. Xx
Posts.Title: The long wait.

Posts.Content: Hello Carolyn28 Thanks for replying, I will probably have loads of questions after my pre op tomorrow so you might regret asking! At the moment I feel shell shocked and almost like it's happening to someone else and not me. The best bit of the day...or middle of the night is when I wake up and for about 1-2 seconds I feel normal, then I remember and my stomach flips over and I'm wide awake.  Anyway I'd better get some housework done as I've been too long on here. Thanks again for the offer.
Posts.Title: The long wait.

Posts.Content: Thanks ronstar,  I really appreciate your reply, just saying that nothing much will change in two weeks has made me feel a bit better. We are trying to get away this weekend to our daughters but are waiting for the ct scan date so we can go. Just want to keep busy and not stare at the four walls. I think my husband needs to take his mind off things too. It's hard for the family. I know I'm causing a lot of distress, and I'm normally the one who calms things down and puts things in perspective for everyone else.  I'm so glad I joined now, thanks again.
Posts.Title: The long wait.

Posts.Content: Hello Daisy10 I'm so sorry you've got to go back for another operation, and to have to cancel it last week, what a stress. It's awful the waiting isn't it, I'm trying to keep busy. After the pre op tomorrow we are going to pack up and go to see my daughter and parents in law on Thursday in Devon, back on Monday, I just can't stand the thought of sitting here waiting and worrying. Got Ct scan Tuesday, bone scan Wednesday, then the final few days till admission to the hospital on Monday. I never thought I'd be looking forward to a mastectomy that's for sure, but I just want it over and done with now. I've kind of convinced myself that it's spread as it's so uncomfortable and the cyst is really big now but there's nothing at all I can do about it. I only joined Macmillan today and I'm glad I did, I've seen that even if the worst happens and it has spread, there are good treatments and it sounds like people still have a good quality of life, I have my first grandchild due in December and am desperate to see him grow up as much as I can, so I'm clinging on to anything that will give me hope right now.  My husband said yesterday that this life changing news has created a new 'normal' the last 50 years of normal have gone, the new normal is hospital appointments and hoping for the best. He was right I think. I hope you get your operation on Friday and that this time it works out for you. I've started taking vit c today because I have a tickly throat and I just couldn't bear it if the operation was cancelled, I don't know if it works but I don't suppose it can harm. Wishing you  all the very best for Friday. Xx
Posts.Title: The long wait.

Posts.Content: Hello Jojo4 Nice to hear from you. Its early days but so far so good, today has been the best day since this nightmare began, I keep telling myself that everything will be ok, over and over again when I start to panic.  I think starting the chemo, although daunting was a huge relief to me, and my husband. I got lots of cards from people when they heard the news, but one of my good friends sent me a really beautiful but simple card, one with those words on the front, 'Everything will be OK' I've put away all the other cards in a box with all the appointments and paperwork, because I need to move forward now, but that card is sitting on the book case, reminding me that 'everything will be ok.'  Apart from a soreish mouth over the last couple of days physically I feel ok. I diluted a teaspoon of salt in a pint of water and have been gently swilling my mouth out with that during the day and after I eat. It seems to be doing the trick.  It's going to be ok Jo.  Xxx
Posts.Title: Joining December chemo club.

Posts.Content: Hi Jo,  Thanks for asking, today has been a 'good' day. I've been out with the dogs, keeping busy this morning. Lazy afternoon really, I still feel guilty sitting down doing nothing, it's not like me.  I've come to realise that I can throw as much anxiety at this situation as I can but it won't change a thing, except exhaust me, so I'm trying to stay calm and focused on positive thinking.  I think if I hadn't been given the all clear in the summer I would have more faith in all the scan results and the fact that they've said it's contained in the breast and hasn't spread. I just keep hearing the breast care nurse saying the left breast isn't a concern....look at me now.  How are you jo?  Xxx
Posts.Title: Joining December chemo club.

Posts.Content: Fiddlercrab, that was my fear, coming down with a cold, it still is, I wonder how bad it would be to delay chemo? I suppose everyone is different.  I've been taking a dinner plate sized soluble vit c every morning, and making sure husband has one too, don't want him catching a cold and passing  to me.  I'll be thinking of you on the 6th, don't worry about it though it'll be fine. I found the two weeks of scans and results before much more stressful than the chemotherapy. At least there's a routine to work around now.  All the best to you. Xx
Posts.Title: Joining December chemo club.

Posts.Content: Hello All.  Im joining the December chemo club, although I had my first chemo last Friday. It wasn't as scary as I thought it would be, but I did have my husband with me, and apart from a bit of a sore mouth things are ok, but it's very early days.  I'm just so relieved that the treatment has started now as I'm having the chemotherapy first to shrink the tumour before Mastectomy.
Posts.Title: Joining December chemo club.

Posts.Content: Thanks Crystaljuju, It means such a lot to be able to post on here, and to know that people really do understand exactly how you feel.  Xx
Posts.Title: Joining December chemo club.

Posts.Content: Under par,  Like jojo, I feel exactly the same, I could've written your post myself.   I was devastated when the plan changed to chemo first, but it all makes sense now, and its comforting to know we aren't alone.  I so so hope ultrasound results are good next week. I can see my lump, I'm watching it like a hawk! I'm thinking of  drawing a line or something around to measure it myself....just to make sure it's behaving. Think how strong we will be next year this time!  Take care, and again good luck next week. Xx
Posts.Title: Joining December chemo club.

Posts.Content: Hope it's okay to post here in April as technically I have had my last chemo, but the three weeks after having the last dose isn't quite up! I can't quite say goodbye to the chemo club yet as you've all been such a fantastic help. I don't post too much but I do a lot of reading.  I'm almost back to normal three weeks after the last dose, the watery twitchy eyes are still annoying me, but apart from that I feel fine. Energy levels good, taste buds firing on all cylinders and I'm looking forward to eating all the things on the 'danger' list next week.  So the next bit begins now, I'm going into hospital Monday, operation Tuesday. For anyone just starting chemo, I found it completely doable and not half as bad as I thought it would be, I know everyone is different but apart from a few days I just carried on almost as normal and carried on working. I had one infection after the second FEC which I'm sure was a lady sneezing and coughing on me as I walked inside a shop, but the hospital dealt with it so well and I was home again in a couple of days. It was all fine after that.  So good luck and all the very best to everyone in the April chemo club.  Xx
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: I'll be starting radiotherapy in late May too. I've not been thinking too much about it but now the chemo and surgery are out of the way I'm starting to think about it more and more. Xx
Posts.Title: * * * APRIL Breast cancer chemo club ****

Posts.Content: Hi, mine was 4.2mm and I wouldn't have known it was there but a cyst came up on top of it, when they drained the cyst, they found the lump. I'd already had the all clear just a few weeks before after lots of tests. It has reduced by 50% so far during chemo, two more sessions left to go and a check up today to see if any further shrinkage.
Posts.Title: Curious.....

Posts.Content: Hello LL. I don't have anything fantastic to add to the other suggestions except that I try to do some puzzles, I have an app called 'peak' it's brain training using games which are good fun, hubby, daughter and I all use use it, we all try to beat each other on certain sections, or I try to watch a film or bake a cake, sometimes I bake some scones or something nice and then invite my neighbours around for a cream tea, or I go for a good dog walk.  Really I just wanted to say that we are all waiting with you, willing you on.  I'm waiting for the final results appointment on Friday so I'd better try some of these suggestions myself. Then I'll be waiting for radiotherapy then I'll be waiting for......something else I'm sure. I'm off to bake a cake now..... Xxx
Posts.Title: It doesn't get any easier.....

Posts.Content: Hi jo jo, I want to wish you all the very best for tomorrow. Hope all goes well. I'm two weeks after my op and doing well, no pain and movement back to normal now.  Xx
Posts.Title: Panic setting in before operation

Posts.Content: Hello Jojo, Great to hear you are doing so well, and are spending more time with your family now, you’re right that going through this really is a wake up call. I just popped in to update too as yesterday I just had my first mammogram and ultrasound since the operation and thankfully all was good.  We went through the whole process together at the same time.  I’m so very pleased to hear that things are going well for you and wish you all the very best for the future. Xx
Posts.Title: Popping in to say hello

Posts.Content: Hi Daisylou2, I didn't have the oncotype dx test so I'm afraid I can't help you with any info. With having triple negative breast cancer I was advised to have the chemotherapy first before surgery as it can respond excellently to the chemo and shrink the tumour dramatically. In my case I was very lucky to have a pCR, meaning all traces of cancer had gone by the time of the lumpectomy. I'm sure there someone here will help you with some information on the onoctype test soon.  I had my treatment plan changed at the last minute and found really stressful, it was hard to accept what the experts were telling me at the time, but they really are going to do what's right and best for you. All the best Daisylou2, you'll find lots of help and support from the lovely people here. Xx
Posts.Title: Will oncotype dx results be different?

Posts.Content: Thank you everyone, I really appreciated your kindness last night. I'm going to go and get this over with this morning, I will let you know how I get on. One things for sure, what ever life throws at me from now on, surely it will be easier than this hell of not knowing?  Sending you all a grateful hug. Xx
Posts.Title: Thank you to everyone who offered support last night when I really...

Posts.Content: That's the best news! Im so so pleased for you. I don't know you, but everyone here is fighting this same battle and any victory over it is a boost for us all, and gives hope. Good luck for the rest of your treatment.  Xx
Posts.Title: biopsy results
